description:
Vash the Stampede is a wanted man with a habit of turning entire towns into rubble. The price on his head is a fortune, and his path of destruction reaches across the arid wastelands of a desert planet. Unfortunately, most encounters with the spiky-haired gunslinger don't end well for the bounty hunters who catch up with him; someone almost always gets hurt - and it's never Vash.

Oddly enough, for such an infamous fugitive, there's no proof that he's ever taken a life. In fact, he's a pacifist with a doughnut obsession who's more doofus than desperado. There's a whole lot more to him than his reputation lets on - Vash the Stampede definitely ain't your typical outlaw.

(Source: Funimation)

tags.name: Guns
tags.description: Prominently features the use of guns in combat.

tags.name: Fugitive
tags.description: Prominently features a character evading capture by an individual or organization.

tags.description: Main character is male.

tags.name: Philosophy
tags.description: Relating or devoted to the study of the fundamental nature of knowledge, reality, and existence.

tags.description: Main cast is mostly composed of characters above a high school age.

tags.description: Features Western or Western-inspired cowboys.

tags.name: Tragedy
tags.description: Centers around tragic events and unhappy endings.

tags.name: Post-Apocalyptic
tags.description: Partly or completely set in a world or civilization after a global disaster.

tags.name: Crime
tags.description: Centers around unlawful activities punishable by the state or other authority.

tags.description: Prominently features a desert environment.

tags.name: Travel

tags.name: Steampunk
tags.description: Prominently features technology and designs inspired by 19th-century industrial steam-powered machinery.

tags.name: Shounen
tags.description: Target demographic is teenage and young adult males.

tags.name: Episodic
tags.description: Features story arcs that are loosely tied or lack an overarching plot.

tags.name: Twins
tags.description: Prominently features two or more siblings that were born at one birth.

tags.name: Incest
tags.description: Features sexual or romantic relations between characters who are related by blood.

tags.name: Aliens
tags.description: Prominently features extraterrestrial lifeforms.

tags.name: Space
tags.description: Partly or completely set in outer space.

tags.name: Slapstick
tags.description: Prominently features comedy based on deliberately clumsy actions or embarrassing events.

tags.name: Acrobatics
tags.description: The art of jumping, tumbling, and balancing. Often paired with trapeze, trampolining, tightropes, or general gymnastics.

tags.name: Rural
tags.description: Partly or completely set in the countryside.

tags.name: Religion
tags.description: Centers on the belief that humanity is related to supernatural, transcendental, and spiritual elements.

tags.name: Body Horror
tags.description: Features characters who undergo horrific transformations or disfigurement, often to their own detriment.

node.description:
[Twitter](https://twitter.com/i/user/136171134)

A long-serving anime producer, as well as a founder of [Madhouse](https://anilist.co/studio/11/), [Mappa](https://anilist.co/studio/569/) and [Studio M2](https://anilist.co/studio/6137/). He currently serves as the Chairman of the Board at [Mappa](https://anilist.co/studio/569/).

Maruyama graduated from Hosei University in 1963, and soon after, he found work at [Mushi Production](https://anilist.co/studio/68/) in 1965. It was here that he met many of Madhouse's future staff members. In October 1972, he left Mushi Production together with [Rintarou](https://anilist.co/staff/102305/), [Osamu Dezaki](https://anilist.co/staff/100393/) and [Yoshiaki Kawajiri](https://anilist.co/staff/100812/) and founded Madhouse. From that time onward, Maruyama focused mainly on producing and planning Madhouse's upcoming projects. He also served as the studio's president through the '80s and '90s.

Thanks in large part to his frequent attendance at anime conventions, he has become well-known in America among Madhouse's fanbase. Not simply wanting to emulate past successes, Maruyama frequently says at these events that his goal as a producer is to seek out new challenges that will allow the production staff to keep experimenting. This attitude in part has been the reason why he has encouraged the studio to take on projects that may not seem like sure-fire commercial hits. In addition, Maruyama has long been a supporter of bringing new talents into the animation business, and continues to encourage young people to work in anime.

In 2011, he left Madhouse and founded Mappa. Later in 2016, he left Mappa and founded Studio M2.

(Source: Wikipedia)
Also serves as a music director.

Yasuhiro Nightow is a Japanese manga artist and game creator who created the anime and manga Trigun. Nightow was born in Yokohama, Japan. He moved to Yokosuka when he was in elementary school, and spent the junior high and high school years in Shizuoka.

Before the release of the popular manga, Trigun, Nightow studied social science and then majored in media studies. Nightow became popular in the US thanks to the US release of Trigun. Trigun, the TV series, had a limited broadcast run in 1998.

Nightow also created the characters and story for the Sega/Red Entertainment anime and third-person shooter video game series Gungrave.

(Source: Wikipedia)

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/nightow)

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/本田保則) | [Wiki (en)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yasunori_Honda)

Founder and representative director of Arts Pro.
He ran an editing studio called Ogata Henshuushitsu from 1996 to 2001.

__Date of Birth:__ December 5, 1962

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/今堀恒雄)

Tsuneo Imahori is a Japanese guitarist and composer, and has worked with [Youko Kanno](https://anilist.co/staff/95508/) as a member of [The Seatbelts](https://anilist.co/staff/193673/).

He started to play acoustic guitar at the age of twelve, inspired by British folk music from the likes of Bert Jansch, and later the work of Frank Zappa and Andy Partridge. In 1986 he formed the band Tipographica, with saxophonist [Naruyoshi Kikuchi](https://anilist.co/staff/111335/) and jazz pianist Akira Minakami. After four albums, the group disbanded in 1996.

In 2002, after providing the soundtrack for the PS2 video game, Gungrave, the concept was subsequently developed into [an anime series](https://anilist.co/anime/267/), which's score was also handled by Imahori. In addition to scoring the anime series, he composed the music for the video game's sequel Gungrave: Overdose. He is perhaps best known in the US as the composer of several anime soundtracks, primarily [Trigun](https://anilist.co/anime/6/), [Hajime no Ippo](https://anilist.co/anime/263/) and the aforementioned Gungrave.

He has also contributed in tracks, as either a composer or a guitarist, for shows such as [Cowboy Bebop](https://anilist.co/anime/1/), [Wolf's Rain](https://anilist.co/anime/202/), [Texhnolyze](https://anilist.co/anime/26/), [NieA Under 7](https://anilist.co/anime/800/) and [Oh! My Goddess](https://anilist.co/anime/50/).

(Source: Wikipedia)

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/i/user/75655903) | [Instagram](https://www.instagram.com/something_Yoshimatsu/)

Affiliated with Studio Live since 1982. Studied under [Toyoo Ashida](https://anilist.co/staff/110953/). He has deep ties into [Madhouse](https://anilist.co/studio/11/) ever since working as a character designer on [Trigun](https://anilist.co/anime/6/) in 1998. A member of the Japanese Animation Creators Association (JAniCA).

Works as a mangaka under the name Something Yoshimatsu (サムシング吉松).

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/白井久男)

Founder of Studio Cosmos.

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/MoonRed0831) | [Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/有里紅良)

Studied film editing under [Harutoshi Ogata](https://anilist.co/staff/149439/).
He was an art director working for Atelier Bwca.

Yousuke Kuroda is a Japanese screenwriter. He is affiliated with Studio Orphee and serves as the inside director (board of directors member).

Kuroda is a prolific writer in the anime industry. Having authored and scripted numerous anime series. Including several original productions. Some of the most notable are Infinite Ryvius, Scryed, Please☆Teacher!, Mobile Suit Gundam 00, and Waiting in the Summer.

In 2003, he won the Individual Award at the 8th Animation Kobe event.

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/神宮司訓之)

He does a wide range of design works.
